Here's Peel Hunt to walk us through what's been said.

11:14 am
BE11:15am

Ted Baker reported an interim loss of £2.7m before exceptionals and IFRS 16, falling well short of our forecast of £15m. Back in June, Ted’s trading update/profit warning centred on the tough trading conditions. We cut Retail sales expectations to flat and margins by 120bp to reflect clearance. Retail sales actually fell by 2.5% (4.1% in CC), with margins down 290bs. Excluding the acquisition of No Ordinary Shoes (previously a Pentland-owned license partner), Wholesale revenues fell by 9.8% yoy (down 11.7% CC).

BE11:15am

Management has stepped away from the previous profit guidance of £50-60m PBT, but has not issued any new information. We assume that trading trends remain difficult, with underlying Wholesale revenues down 10% and challenging Retail conditions. We assume margins will remain challenged. Ted has improved working capital by 9% or c£17m over H1, but we expect discount levels in the market to remain significant. Ted is unlikely to be able to maintain its price file given H1 performance; we assume Retail margins fall by c250bp in H2, which is a fairly harsh assessment of the H2 outlook, we believe. With no material cost savings, this results in underlying PBT of £23m, or £16.7m after the effect of IFRS 16. We have pushed similar downgrades to future years, assuming no bounce back in performance.

YourGrannyOnBongos @BE each to their own, I guess, but I'll stick to the Islay single malts if it's all the same
BE11:15am

Brand, product or market? Ted’s woes are no doubt exacerbated by very tough market conditions, but the primary battle, as always, is relevance. Ted quotes a number of positive customer metrics on NPS, new non-seasonal range launches and social media. There’s clearly no customer backlash here. However, our concern is that the price architecture has become considerably more expensive in recent years and that collections have become too consistent with not enough newness in direction. On top of that, a heavy department store weighting to wholesale accounts has also affected routes to market. These issues are not a quick fix, but they are doable. The question is how quickly management will grasp the nettle and drive creative direction.

chomsky Surely these companies must realise the traditional physical presence model is completely outdated
11:16 am
BE11:16am

And Liberum, shop broker, who went cold at 7.30am

BE11:17am

(Shop brokers get an embargoed copy of the RNS don't they? That used to be the case anyway.)

BE11:17am

n unexpectedly poor set of interim results leads us to cut our FY20 PBT estimates by c.39%. Forecasts and outlook have been impacted a very tough market backdrop where discounting is prevalent, and consumer uncertainty has led to unpredictable trading patterns. The Group has done well in addressing the issues it faced in its S/S collection and while the results themselves are very poor, working capital has shown some significant improvement. The management team are taking action on costs, inventory levels have reduced and are flat YoY and there have been a number of initiatives in H1 that should strategically deliver medium term benefits. Considering the scale of the downgrade we temporarily place our recommendation and TP under review

Nate morning
tangledodyssey Soundbuy: "Attired by Boohoo", great slogan.
11:17 am
BE11:18am

And RBC.

Tom Dalgleish Ted Baker reminds me of Leyland cars and those Rollers where the door panels warped over time
BE11:18am

And RBC.

BE11:18am

Difficult 1H20 trading conditions, with significant PBT declines suggests things are not getting better for TED from a P&L perspective. Material gross margin dilution points to high promotion and inventory clearance which has benefited working capital.

September current trading comments also cautious due to warm weather however this could improve in the coming weeks/months.

The magnitude of the 1H PBT miss (~£20m) puts the previous FY £50-60m PBT guide out of reach, and we would expect to see significant downward revisions to consensus (currently at ~£50m).

11:18 am
BE11:18am

We rate Ted Baker Sector Perform with a GBP 9 price target. Our Sector Perform rating reflects the operational negatives offset by the valuation (and potential bid) positives.

The growth prospects for the business have largely dissipated, with major markets experiencing structural and transient headwinds that are unlikely to recede in the next 12 months.

TED's pricing strategy appears to be disconnected with its brand/quality proposition, evidenced by material entry price hikes in categories such as men's blazers (+30% in the past twelve months), and broader and deeper markdowns vs peers in core categories such as men's polo t-shirts and shirts.

The disruption in the apparel industry from declining traditional distribution channels (stores, department stores) and the growth of online (direct and multi-brand) is driving excessive choice and ill-disciplined pricing behaviours in the marketplace.

Coupled with persistent adverse weather relative to traditional fashion cycle selling periods is accentuating the markdown issue that brands such as TED (and others face) whilst lead times remain 6m+ for main collections.

Valuation is a supporting factor in TED's equity story; however, we do not anticipate a sustained re-rating given investor apathy towards premium apparel and UK exposure at this point in the cycle. Potential corporate action could offer respite, should any bids materialise; however, any approach would have to be ratified by the founder and majority shareholder who would be appraising offers at trough valuation.

YourGrannyOnBongos @Soundbuy - it's anecdotal but a move amongst some people to buying secondhand or avoiding buying new clothes at all for environmental reasons. Also, Primark.
Soundbuy Whyte & Mackay does the job..............or stick it into an empty single malt bottle for the more discerning....

Jefferies:

Tom Dalgleish Affordable spiv is timeless so TB should survive but Superdry is demographic cliche and is in trouble
BE11:20am

Ted's woes have continued with a sharp deterioration in sales over the
summer (e.g. retail sales down c.-8% for 9 weeks to 11 Aug) and calling out a slow start to 2H (6 weeks to end Sept) - which is not unexpected given the warm weather and low consumer confidence but Ted does seem to be faring worse than other retailers. Co warns that 2H20E profits could be lower than a year ago (PBT £38m) which, combined with the reported pre exceptional IFRS 16 PBT loss of £2.7m in 1H20, could lead to consensus FY20E PBT falling more than 30% (from £51.5m given guidance of £50-60m) to under £35m. Ted is taking a number of initiatives to improve the business, and we welcome the appointment of Rachel Osborne as CFO, but we see little support to Ted's share price, even trading on 10x (current) consensus PER.

11:20 am
BE11:20am

Goldman:

BE11:21am

Other things equal, the c.£16mn 1H20 profit miss and a lower 2H20E EBIT vs last year, would imply Bloomberg consensus FY20E PBT could reduce more than £16m to less than £35m. This assumes FY20E cFX Retail sales c.-4%LFL -6% (from -1%-3%), Wholesale sales c.+7% (from +7.5%).
Valuation: Our DCF-based 12m PT is 1,000p, which equates to a 10x FY21E EV/EBIT multiple (10.2x P/E). Our rating remains Neutral.

11:29 am
BE11:30am

There was very little to cheer in this release. The employment index fell to its lowest level since 2010, with 19% of firms reporting cuts to the workforce, albeit through attrition rather than redundancies. Business optimism dropped to its lowest since July 2016 (the kneejerk postreferendum low). Meanwhile, the margin squeeze continued, with 11 points between the input cost index and the prices charged index

BornCynic @Soundbuy - that's people in Denmark.
BE11:30am

The three PMI surveys for the UK in September make for gloomy reading. Indeed, today's print may even revive speculation that the UK is in a recession. Markit, which compiles the surveys, thinks that the results so far point to a q-o-q fall of 0.1% in UK GDP in Q3, following the confirmed 0.2% fall in Q2. However, this does not take into account the 0.3% m-o-m rise in GDP in July. Unless this is revised away, full quarter growth is likely to be positive. However, we will know more next week with the August GDP print.
Companies surveyed by Markit blamed Brexit related uncertainty for some of their woes, reporting, for example, that clients were delaying orders as a consequence of the uncertainty. From that perspective, there might be some upside risk in the event of a deal being done and some clarity emerging. However, this still seems some way off, and the global economic backdrop is not encouraging even if the UK political one improves.

BE11:30am

More broadly though, the UK economy has clearly lost momentum, and for the all-important service sector, which accounts for 80% of GDP, to be in contraction is a worrying sign. The BoE has been incrementally less hawkish in its communications and today's data will further affirm the market's belief that the next move is down, not up. As we have argued before, the margin squeeze firms are feeling at the moment can lead to either inflation or job cuts, and the BoE's response will depend on which outcome materialises. For now, the signs are pointing towards the latter.

Oversupply and a cautious consumer continue to weigh on performance. The outlook for the legacy casual dining brands looks bleak with c50% of sites earmarked for exit, and a £116m impairment/onerous lease provision taken. In contrast Wagamama continues to outperform with the extension into USA, food-to-go, concession and delivery all offering long term opportunities. Overall management is slowing expansion to focus on debt reduction however visibility is low and earnings risk remains to the downside. We downgrade forecasts and cut our TP once again.

Forester Major flurry of CEO stepdowns of major groups this week. Coincidence or are they reading the runes?
BE11:45am

With CEY having managed expectations lower on Q3 already with its Denver Gold Forum presentation today just broadly confirms what we already knew, albeit with new 9 month YTD production now confirmed as being c. -9% below RBCe. This was primarily due to reduced open pit mining rates on the higher-grade Stage 4 West wall. The group is again reiterating the low end of the FY guidance range at 490koz (vs. initial range of 490-520koz). This compares to our current 497koz FY forecast. The 490koz implies production of 158-159koz in Q4 which would be a record quarter for Sukari mine making today’s reiteration somewhat of a stretch in our view. Previous highest production quarters at the mine were 157koz and 155koz in Q3 and Q4 of 2017, respectively. We don’t necessarily think this run rate of production is not achievable given the open pit was mining in the same higher grade Hapi zone at the time. However, the
underground grade averaged +8g/t in the record quarters vs. H1 2019 at 5.6g/t so we think a big step up will be required there to deliver the plan. Overall, we see
the reiteration as creating another potentially unnecessary pressure point for the operating team, albeit this time under a new COO who joined earlier in 2019.

2s10s So Trade War part deux
Sails I quite like the Italian approach of "bring you stuff when it's ready", or indeed the Greek one of "Bring you lukewarm stuff when we feel like it" (only works in a beach restaurant when you've been stunned by the sun though)
1st Lt. Fletcher Christian I have to say though Wagamama's food is served hot and is tasty.
BE11:46am

That's RBC.

11:46 am
BE11:46am

The other news today was that after 12 years with CEY, CEO Andrew Pardey has announced his intentions to retire. Mr Pardey has overseen Sukari moving from start up to being one of the top 20 gold mines globally during his time in the role. A global search for a new CEO is underway with an orderly handover planned within his 12-month notice period.
Summary: CEY confirmed production for the first nine months of 2019 will be lower than initially guided due to reduced open pit mining rates on the highergrade Stage 4 West wall. Production from January to September is now expected to be 331-332koz, -9% lower than RBCe 360Koz. The company reiterated
that the lower end of full year guidance (490koz) remains achievable as higher-grade material at both the open pit and underground is planned to be mined in Q4. Also today, Andrew Pardey announced its intention to retire as CEO. He will stay in the company for a 12 month notice period while the Nomination Committee finds a new candidate. CEY report Q3 results on the 23rd of October.

Sails @Fletcher have had varying experiences at Wagamamas and distrust them now
BE11:47am

And Morgan Stanley.

Grouchmonkey @Forester not sure they have had much option in the decision to step down, in a number of cases.
BE11:47am

Centamin have announced today that the CEO has announced his intention to retire, and will complete a handover to a successor within a 12 month period. We see this as a neutral development, with the loss of his knowledge of the operation offset by the potential benefit of a new pair of eyes given the significant volatility in operational results in recent years. Also in the release the company commented that Q3 is going to be a weaker quarter, with production of 97-98koz. We had assumed 128koz. The reason for the lower volumes being lower mining rates from the open pit. The company has stated it thinks it can still hit the bottom end of the guidance range of 490koz, but that would require just under 160koz of production in 4Q. The record for a quarter is 157koz, so this looks a tough target to hit. We had assumed 499koz for the full year, so estimate around 3% cut to EBITDA from this update. Whilst this looks manageable on the face of it, investors may question the longer-term outlook after what is essentially another profit warning.

#REF! I'd vote for RNS when market closes. Purely selfish reasons, house broker analysts not working late in night to make note for 7am open (after having worked from 7am). instead would be let inside during the working day

11:47 am
BE11:48am

Sails Really Soundbuy, hmmm okay...
BE11:48am

CEY has also flagged that Q3 production is likely to be in the 97-98koz range, which is significantly below our expectations (133koz), but also potentially below the weak Q2 18 result of only 98koz. Centamin has also stated that the lower end of 2019 annual production guidance of 490koz “remains achievable”, which is not necessarily a high conviction statement. We would expect further downgrades near term considering the fact that in order to deliver the lower end of guidance CEY would have to deliver a record quarter (ie, even higher than Q4 17).

BE11:48am

However, considering the complexity of the Sukari orebody and its recent
operational volatility relative to guidance, we also think that a reassessment by the Board and management is no bad thing. Better sustainable operational direction is needed at CEY considering that a 2-3 year operation review had been delivered just ahead of today’s news of a Q3 19 miss. The market does need more sustainable conviction in operational capability at Sukari in our view.

JuB any colour FLTR/TSG ?

11:48 am
BE11:49am

It also worth remembering that CEY has recently announced an interim dividend that implies a c5% dividend yield – again under Andrew’s tenure as CEO. CEY is currently the highest-yielding gold stock and most liquid of those in our coverage, which should provide some comfort to investors during the transition period.

From the United Kingdom: Single-malt (or straight) Irish and Scotch Whiskies. This should affect Pernod Ricard (The Glenlivet; c6% US sales) and Diageo (Various single malt Scotches; less than 1% US sales).
 From Germany, Ireland, Italy, Spain, or the UK: Liqueurs and Cordials. This should affect Campari (Campari, Aperol, Frangelico; c13% US sales) and Diageo (Baileys; c6% US sales).
 From France, Germany, Spain or the UK: Still wine, below 14% ABV, in containers not over 2L. De minimis impact on our coverage.

While we believe these are just the 1st steps in a potential trade war escalation, we are surprised by the limited nature of the tariffs, especially as regards to the absence of duties on brandy/cognac, sparkling wines and French liqueurs. A worst case scenario for European spirits, especially for Remy Cointreau (Underweight; up to 10% group gross profit on our estimates) seemingly avoided. Prima facie, given the restrictive terms of the preliminary list, we see c1% of Pernod Ricard (PR, Overweight) group sales at risk, 2% for Diageo (Neutral) and 3% for Campari (Underweight); from our reading, Remy Cointreau is not affected by these tariffs (very small Scotch whisky sales exposure)

BE12:00pm

Very small impact on Pernod Ricard and Diageo
Pernod Ricard and Diageo both sell single-malt Scotch whiskies in the US,
but we estimate that this is only a very small part of their overall US
business. We expect that these companies will try to pass on at least part
of the tariff in the price. Given the premium character of the product, this is
probably easier than it is blended scotch for example. Finally, there are
likely to be some liqueur exports to the US as well, for example Baileys
from Diageo, but this is again a relatively small part of the overall business.
Estimated 1.5% impact on Campari EBIT
As indicated, liqueurs and cordials from Italy are included on the import
tariffs list. We estimate that the value of exports of Campari from Italy into
the US could be EUR25-30m, implying a potential hike of EUR6-7m, which
is about 1.5% of expected 2019 EBIT. In an interview yesterday, the CEO
of Campari said that if tariffs were to be applied, Campari would still have
the option to move the production of Campari and Aperol to its US plants.
Hence, we do not expect a structural impact on earnings.
No impact on Rémy Cointreau
We have flagged Rémy Cointreau as the company that is most at risk from
US import tariffs. The fact that cognac is no longer on the final list of
products, implies that Rémy Cointreau will not face any negative impact.
The company had shipped more products to the US ahead of the possible
implementation of tariffs and in preparation for the key Christmas selling
season.
